segments.text: Sir, how were you treated on your journey?
I was treated fine.
I grew up in a small town in Texas with about 35,000 people, and everyone was glad to have me back.
And with being from Texas and in our field community in Texas, I found the people to be very conservative.
They wanted to find out what I was all about.
I did not receive a clear weapon opinion.
From there, I went to Camp Finland, so I was on the military base, associating with military people.
When you're living on a base and working on a base, you're not exposed or you don't have to deal with a lot of those things.
It was anti-military.
I just didn't have an opportunity to experience any of those things.
Obviously, the papers and the .
But you're a really nice lady .
Do you think the one-year tour of duty was sufficient time to orient a man to the fighting in Vietnam and then being able to utilize those skills?
Oh, absolutely.
One year may be too long, by the fact.
First of all, you're supposed to have your skills before you go over there.
There's also a training.
You have to train people once they get there.
You've got to hone those skills.
I found that as far as the wing captains went that had rifle companies, they probably, if they survived the first
six weeks to survive the entire tour, because you come combat savvy.
I felt that I probably was at the peak of my profession about the third month of combat.
And I stayed on that crest for a couple of months.
About the fifth or sixth month,
I felt that I had peaked out and recovered and worked out.
It's an awesome responsibility to help 200, up to 280 people.
When you're out there by yourself with no visible means of support.
You're in charge of everything.
You're in charge of the shops by all the time.
I never got a full night's sleep.
I had them wake me up every hour and give me a situation report.
When you're deprived of your sleep, you wear it on very quickly.
But it was absolutely necessary to make sure that that machine was up and running 24 hours a day.
That was a responsibility I couldn't delegate to anyone else.
So it's about a year long now.
Depends, obviously depends on the job, but as company commander,
I was not mentally as strong in the sixth month as I was in the fourth month.
As far as the brain goes, again, it depends on each guy.
The guy that leads the hunt, or patrols, or combat moves, literally tunes out, in my view.
That's the way he avoids middle strength.
He disengages his brain.
He's functioning.
His senses are alert to what's going on around him.
He tries not to think about, if I go around this tree or come around this rock, that when I cross that river, I'm going to get shot.
He just can't think like that.
So I believe that they mentally came down to it.
They weren't in a trance, but mentally, they're out of purity.
And that's the way they survived.
Thirteen months is a long time to be over there, knowing that at any time, the enemy could engage you.
You had to do something to prepare yourself for that.
You stated that after an individual made
six weeks here, they had a pretty good chance of making it out of the country.
What about the short timers?
How was their attitude and how did they react in the field?
The short timers were very concerned.
The last six weeks, for most of them, I think, they just feared that something would happen.
When you reach the midpoint of
13 months, it was called, over the month, you're on the downhill side.
Until then, you really don't think about it anymore.
But, as you get closer to finishing up your tour in combat, you start thinking about, am I going to make it?
Are we going to, what's going to happen to me the next time we get into a fight?
I would say the last six weeks, the last two weeks in particular.
In your opinion, sir, what were the major causes for losing the war?
Lack of support from the United States.
There were many things that contributed to that.
The protesters, the press that gave a lot of support to that, made it miserable for everyone.
Because of the lack of support, I think the politicians fought the war and let it off.
Militarily, we won the war, and we could have won the war, but the political decisions, labor, the battle was fought politically.
Would it possibly influence the outcome of the war in favor of the United States?
Anything, let's say, within the South Vietnamese government?
The South Vietnamese government has not been corrupt.
They may have had more support by the Vietnamese.
They've been able to take care of their own country.
That was not the situation.
To me, it looked like a time bomb waiting for its throat, even when I was there in 1969.
Those people had been in the war for many years before the Americans went over there in 1965.
It was business as usual.
They walked in here and made a common deal.
They identified that they had strong family ties.
They had seen the governments come and go.
They were all corrupt.
They were taxed heavily.
And I think there was very little support from the government.
The war was a way of life for them.
It was a matter of time until they settled in.
Are there any further comments you would like to make, sir?
No, I don't think so, Mary.
